{{Infobox political party | name = Agrarian Party | native_name = Partito Agrario | logo = | foundation = 1920 | dissolution = 1924 | leader = [[Pietro Lanza di Scalea]] | newspaper = | membership_year= | membership = | ideology = [[Agrarianism]]
[[Conservatism]] | position = [[Right-wing politics|Right-wing]] | international = | european = | europarl = | colorcode = #006600 | country = Italy }} The '''Agrarian Party''' ({{lang-it|Partito Agrario}}) was a [[list of political parties in Italy|political party in Italy]]. It was the principal party of reference of the land owners and it was characterized by an economist vision and a conservative and reactionary tendency. Its principal exponents were the prince [[Pietro Lanza di Scalea]] (minister of the war in the first Government Facta and Minister of the colonies in the Government Mussolini from June 3, 1924 to November 6, 1926), [[Francesco Saverio d'Ayala]] and [[Giovanni Lo Monte]]. In 1924 the principal exponents of the Agrarian Party merged the [[National List (Italy)|National List]]. {{Historical Italian political parties}} [[Category:Defunct political parties in Italy]] [[Category:Political parties established in 1920]] [[Category:Political parties disestablished in 1924]] [[Category:Conservative parties in Italy]] [[Category:1920 establishments in Italy]] [[Category:1924 disestablishments in Italy]] [[Category:Agrarian parties]]

{{flagdeco|Chile}} [[José Toribio Merino]] | commander2 = {{flagicon image|Flag of the MIR - Chile.svg}} [[Andrés Pascal Allende]]
{{flagicon image|Flag of the MIR - Chile.svg}} [[Miguel Enríquez (politician)|Miguel Enríquez]]{{KIA}}
{{flagicon image|FPMR Chile.SVG}} [[Galvarino Apablaza|Sergio Apablaza]]
{{flagicon image|FPMR Chile.SVG}} [[Raúl Pellegrin]]{{executed}}
{{flagicon image|Bandera del MAPU, partit xilè.svg}} Guillermo Ossandón Cañas | units1 = | units2 = | strength1 = | strength2 = | casualties1 = | casualties2 = | notes = | campaignbox = }} Beginning with the [[1973 Chilean coup d'état]], an armed leftist resistance movement against [[Military dictatorship of Chile (1973–90)]] developed until 1990 when [[Chilean transition to democracy|democracy was restored]]. The main armed resistance groups of the period were the [[Revolutionary Left Movement (Chile)|Revolutionary Left Movement]] (MIR) and [[Manuel Rodríguez Patriotic Front|Frente Patriótico Manuel Rodríguez]] (FPMR), the armed wing of the [[Communist Party of Chile]]. These groups had a long-standing rivalry. Key events during the armed resistance were the attempt to set up guerrilla camps in [[Neltume]] in 1970-73''"In September 1973 and again in September 1981, the forest complex of Panguipulli (especially Neltume), only 115 kilometres east of Valdivia, became the focal point of alleged subversive attacks and shoot-outs and a site of massive military operations leading to executions. Panguipulli indeed served as a zone of political organizing, land invasion, and agrarian reform during 1970-73, and as a camping zone for MIRistas reentering Chile under Operacion Retorno in 1980-81."'' Battling for Hearts and Minds, Steve J. Stern, p. 288, Duke University Press and 1980-81, the February 1986 sabotaging of the Limache train tracks, the [[Carrizal Bajo]] arms smuggling operation in August 1986 and the attempted killing of Pinochet in September that same year. After the return to democracy was initiated in 1990 the bulk of the armed groups demobilized. However, splinter groups that reportedly switched targets after the dictatorship fell, continued to carry out assassinations, bombings, kidnappings and armed robberies until 2010. ==Pre-dictatorship violence== The first major action by the MIR took place in September 1967 during violent clashes between MIR-led students from the University of Concepción and riot police. ''Carabineros'' were seeking to arrest those responsible for destroying a police vehicle, but students reorganized and kidnapped carabinier Héctor Gutiérrez Orellana. Chilean president [[Eduardo Nicanor Frei Montalva]] sought to defuse the situation through intermediaries and obtained the release of the policeman in exchange for dropping charges against students earlier arrested in the confrontations.Determinants of Gross Human Rights Violations by State and State Sponsored Actors in Brazil, Uruguay, Chile and Argentina: 1960 - 1990, Wolfgang S. Heinz, Hugo Frühling, p. 423, Martinus Nijhoff Publishers, 1999 During 1968, the MIR presence continued to be felt in various universities with armed actions increasing in 1969 through multiple acts of vandalism, intimidation and physical assaults on conservative/right wing students and faculty members. On 1 May 1969, fifteen MIR activists armed with knives took over the Bio Bio radio station in Concepción and transmitted a special broadcast calling for the locals to take up arms and overthrow the government of Frei. On 2 May 1969, MIR activists operating in Concepción attacked the branches of ''National City Bank'', the building of the ''La Patria'' newspaper and the offices of the ''Weigner Stein'' business. In June, the MIR kidnapped journalist Hernán Osses Santa María, Director of the ''Noticias de la Tarde'' in nearby Talcahuano (15.6 kilometres), in an effort to silence the in depth reporting on the leftist violence in Concepción. Police Investigations and ''Carabineros'' soon surrounded the University of Concepción and forced the students to release the newspaper director unharmed. A specially appointed judge was soon named and a criminal suit was filed with the Courts of Appeals of Concepción against the MIR and over 20 of its identified leaders for breaking the Law of Interior Security of the State. Consequently, the MIR had no option but to go largely underground and into hiding. In the ensuing police and military operations against the MIR, a guerrilla training camp is discovered in San José de Maipo (Guayacán) and another at Corral (Chaihuín).''"En 1969 se descubre una escuela de guerrilleros en San José de Maipo (Guayacán) y en 1970 otra en Corral (Chaihuín)."'' Régimen de Gobierno y Partidos Políticos en Chile 1924-1973, Bernardino Bravo Lira, p. 301, Editorial Jurídica de Chile, 1986 Nevertheless, MIR guerrillas continue to operate, and in Santiago alone carry out 12 armed robberies of banks and businesses between August 1969 and September 1970 to finance their operations.''"Entre agosto de ese año y septiembre siguiente realiza en Santiago no menos de 12 asaltos a mano armada contra Bancos y locales comerciales."'' Régimen de Gobierno y Partidos Políticos en Chile 1924-1973, Bernardino Bravo Lira, p. 301, Editorial Jurídica de Chile, 1986 The Revolutionary Left Movement [[Revolutionary Left Movement (Chile)|(MIR)]] were absolved of criminal charges under an amnesty under the Popular Unity (''Unidad Popular'' or UP) government of [[Salvador Allende|Allende]] and was allowed to operate again openly, encouraging and carrying out illegal [[Chilean land reform|expropriations of farms]] and businesses, and assaulting outspoken conservatives/rightist members of the public and security forces. According to police figures submitted to the Chilean senate, 1,458 farms were illegally occupied between November 1970 and December 1971.''The Overthrow of Allende and the Politics of Chile, 1964–1976'', Paul E. Sigmund, p. 139, University of Pittsburgh, 1977 Starting in the southern provinces of Cautin and Malleco the MIR organized a series of armed takeovers or ''tomas'' working slowly northwards up into the provinces of Nuble and Linares and eventually Santiago."Starting in the southern provinces of Cautin and Malleco the MIR organised a series of violent tomas working slowly northwards up into the provinces of Nuble and Linares and the province of Santiago itself." The Santiago Model-2: Polarisation of Politics, Volume 2, Robert Moss, p. 4, Institute for the Study of Conflict, 1973 In November 1970, Antonia Maechel, owner of the La Tregua estate in the [[Panguipulli]] area, took her own life after being raped by leftist militants that had seized her property. On 6 February 1970, [[Carabineros de Chile|carabineer]] Luis Merino Ferreira was killed in a clash with guerrillas. On 11 August 1970, MIR guerrillas killed carabineer corporal Luis Fuentes Pineda. On 21 September 1970, guerrillas shot and killed a carabineer corporal, Armando Cofré López, during a [[bank robbery]] in the suburb of Irarrázabal in Santiago. On 3 November 1970, another carabinier (Corporal Luis Armando Cofré) is killed in a shoot-out with MIR guerrillas robbing a ''Banco Panamericano'' branch. In April 1971, Juan Millalonco, a member of Christian Democratic Youth, was shot dead in [[Aysén Region|Aysén]] by socialist militants, and VOP guerrillas in Santiago killed 33-year-old Raúl Méndez Espinosa at his sweet shop for not paying protection money to the guerrillas targeting small businesses.La Violencia Política Popular en las "Grandes Alamedas": La Violencia en Chile, 1947-1987, Gabriel Salazar Vergara, p, 259, Lom Ediciones, 2006 That same month in the expropriation of land on the part of leftist militants and guerrillas, Rolando Matus is shot dead resisting the takeover of the Carén farm in [[Pucón]], and Jorge Baraona and Domitila Palma died resisting the takeover of their farms in southern Chile. On 24 May 1971, VOP guerrillas in an armed robbery of a bank money transfer van shoot and mortally wound a carabinier (Corporal José Arnaldo Gutiérrez Urrutia) and wound two other accompanying ''Miramar'' supermarket employees.''La Verdad Olvidada Del Terrorismo en Chile, 1968–1996'', Arturo Castillo Vicencio, p. 67, Editorial Maye Ltda., 2007 In June 1971, VOP guerrillas killed [[Edmundo Perez Zujovic]], a Christian Democrat and former interior minister. That same month, another marxist guerrilla (46-year-old Heriberto Salazar) of the VOP walked into police headquarters in Santiago with a sub-machinegun and kills three detectives (Gerardo Romero Infante, Heriberto Mario Marín and Carlos Pérz Bretti) before blowing himself up with dynamite,[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=N0UaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=cCkEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5023,3675116&dq= Chilean kills 2 Officers, Himself], ''The Milwaukee Journal'', Jun 17, 1971La Violencia Política Popular en las "Grandes Alamedas": La Violencia en Chile, 1947-1987, Gabriel Salazar Vergara, p, 260, Lom Ediciones, 2006 and a carabineer corporal (Jorge Cartes) is killed by MIR guerrillas in the MIR stronghold of Concepción. On 1 December 1971, 50,000-200,000"Opposition newspapers in Chile reported anywhere from 50,000 and 200, 000 demonstrators. Well-dressed upper-class women arrived in cars, while working-class women and members of the pobladora and peasant organizations came in buses." Why Women Protest: Women's Movements in Chile, Lisa Baldez, p. 78, Cambridge University Press, 2002 women took to the streets of Santiago to protest against Salvador Allende’s UP government.[http://www.dsausa.org/women_and_pots_and_pans Women and Pots and Pans: Chile Then and Venezuela Today] Their peaceful march turned ugly when UP radicals attacked the women with rocks.''"The peaceful march turned violent when young UP supporters pelted the demonstrators with rocks."'' International Journal of Group Tensions, Volume 24, Sage Publications, 1994 However, their ''March of the Empty Pots and Pans'' signaled the beginning of a massive coordinated anti-Allende movement. To keep the memory afresh of the march, women in the middle-class and affluent suburbs of Santiago banged on pots every night for two hours for several months."To keep the memory of the debacle fresh, women banged on pots every night between 8 and 10 PM for several months after the march." Women and Revolution in Africa, Asia and the New World, Mary Ann Tétreault, p. 404, University of South Carolina Press, 1994 On 30 August 1972, carabineer corporal Exequiel Aroca Cuevas was killed in the city of Concepción, when socialist militants open fire on the bus he was travelling. On 27 February 1973, MIR guerrillas attacked the Llanquihue police station, shooting and wounding 10 carabineers.Breve Historia de la Unidad Popular, Teresa Donoso Loero, p. 300, El Mercurio, 1973 In March 1973, 16-year-old Germán Enrique González and 17-year-old Sergio Oscar Vergara, both members of the Christian Democrat Party were killed while resisting the takeover of the La Reina estate.La Verdad Olvidada del Terrorismo en Chile, 1968-1996, Arturo Castillo Vicencio, p.77, Editorial Maye Ltda, 2007 On 2 April 1973, MIR guerrillas operating in Santiago shoot and kill a police detective, Gabriel Rodríguez Alcaíno.Los Hechos de Violencia en Chile, María de los Angeles Aylwin Ramírez, Soledad Reyes del Villar, p.421, Fundación Libertad y Desarrollo, 2003 In May 1973, Mario Aguilar, a member of the ''Movimiento Patria y Libertad'' is gunned down by leftists in downtown Santiago. On 27 July 1973, a farmer and member of the Christian Democrat Party, Jorge Mena, is surrounded by leftists and clubbed to death in Osorno.La Verdad Olvidada del Terrorismo en Chile, 1968-1996, Arturo Castillo Vicencio, p.80, Editorial Maye Ltda, 2007 The next day, another farmer, Juan Luis Urrutia, dies resisting the takeover of his land in Bulnes. On 30 July, MIR guerrillas kill Manuel Garrido, an employee of ''Paños Continental'' in a confrontation that also involved Brazilian militants. On 27 August 1973, Sergio Aliaga, while driving through a confrontation between anti-Allende striking truckers and leftist militants, was killed after being caught in the crossfire and shot in the throat.La Verdad Olvidada del Terrorismo en Chile, 1968-1996, Arturo Castillo Vicencio, p.82, Editorial Maye Ltda, 2007 On 29 August 1973, a Mexican militant (Jorge Albino Sosa Gil) working in Chile, shoots and kills Second Lieutenant Héctor Lacrampette Calderón as the young army officer was waiting for a bus in the suburb of Providencia in Santiago.''La Verdad Olvidada Del Terrorismo en Chile, 1968–1996'', Arturo Castillo Vicencio, p. 82, Editorial Maye Ltda., 2007 The next day, two farm workers (José Toribio Núñez and Celsa Fuentes) died of horrific burns after being caught in the bomb blast targeting the pipeline between Santiago and [[Concepción, Chile|Concepción]].La Verdad Olvidada del Terrorismo en Chile, 1968-1996, Arturo Castillo Vicencio, p. 81, Editorial Maye Ltda, 2007 ==September–December 1973== After the coup, left-wing guerrilla organizations tried to recruit resistance fighters against the Pinochet regime. Some of them had commando-training, having belonged to the GAP (''Grupo de Amigos Personales''), they had previously served as bodyguards of President Allende. Many activists created resistance groups from refugees abroad. The [[Movimiento Juvenil Lautaro]] or Lautaro Youth Movement (MJL) was formed in December 1982 and the [[Communist Party of Chile]] set up an armed wing, which became in 1983 the [[FPMR]] (''Frente Patriótico Manuel Rodríguez''). The main guerrilla group, known as the [[Revolutionary Left Movement (Chile)|MIR]] (''Movimiento de Izquierda Revolucionaria''), suffered heavy casualties in the coup's immediate aftermath, and most of its members fled the country.[http://www.faqs.org/cia/docs/29/0000451391/TERRORISM-REVIEW---CHILE:-CHANGE-IN-MIR-TACTICS.html Terrorism Review Chile: Change in MIR tactics] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004213752/http://www.faqs.org/cia/docs/29/0000451391/TERRORISM-REVIEW---CHILE%3A-CHANGE-IN-MIR-TACTICS.html |date=October 4, 2013 }} Andreas Pascal Allende, a nephew of President Allende led the MIR from 1974–1976, then made his way to Cuba. Nevertheless, in the first three months of military rule, the Chilean forces recorded 162 military deaths.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8aWQ_7oKJfkC&pg=PA326&lpg=PA326&dq=the+military+sustained+162+dead+as+a+result+of+the+coup&source=bl&ots=YOzpGJ4smb&sig=bhUWRdySLpMlg2GA5Qb1JPgKHxk&hl=en&ei=jmyGSuTFJqaW6wO5nannAw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1#v=onepage&q=&f=false|title=Latin America's Wars Volume II|publisher=}} It is claimed that a total of 756 servicemen and police are reported to have been killed or wounded in clashes with guerrillas in the 1970s.{{cite web|title=El terrorismo de los años 70 |url=http://www.analitica.com/va/internacionales/opinion/9892262.asp |work= |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jWiebcA3?url=http://www.analitica.com/va/internacionales/opinion/9892262.asp |archivedate=2009-09-04 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2009-08-31 }} {{Unreliable source?|date=March 2017}} Among the killed and disappeared during the military regime were at least 663 Marxist [[Revolutionary Left Movement (Chile)|MIR]] guerrillas.[http://www.archivochile.com/Derechos_humanos/doc_gen_ddhh/hhdddocgen0002.pdf CAIDOS DEL MIR EN DIFERENTE PERIODOS. CEME (CENTRO DE ESTUDIOS MIGUEL ENRIQUEZ).] The MIR commander, [[Andrés Pascal Allende]], has admitted that the Marxist guerrillas lost 1,500-2,000 fighters killed or disappeared.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bJ2-wUrZn8IC&pg=PA155&dq=|title=Los Allende|publisher=}} Many guerrillas confessed under torture and several hundred other young men and women, sympathetic to the guerrillas, were detained and tortured and often killed. Nearly 700 civilians disappeared in the 1974-1977 period, after being detained by the Chilean military and police.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/13/world/new-chilean-leader-announces-political-pardons.html|title=New Chilean Leader Announces Political Pardons|date=13 March 1990|work=New York Times}} Remnants of the MIR also joined Marxist guerrillas from the [[People's Revolutionary Army (Argentina)]] (''Ejército Revolucionario del Pueblo'' or ERP) in Argentina in the protracted fight to control Tucumán Province. Some 30,000 former Chilean conscripts that served between 1973 and 1990, claiming to be suffering from post-traumatic stress after taking part in the cordon and search operations and night curfews, are currently seeking compensation from the Chilean government.{{cite web|url=http://www.cooperativa.cl/noticias/pais/ff-aa-y-de-orden/ejercito/propuesta-del-gobierno-no-dejo-satisfechos-a-ex-conscriptos-de-la-dictadura/2013-03-25/215147.html|title=Propuesta del Gobierno no dejó satisfechos a ex conscriptos de la dictadura|publisher=Cooperativa.cl}} Fewer than 60 individuals died as a direct result of fighting on 11 September although the [[Revolutionary Left Movement (Chile)|MIR]] and GAP continued to fight the following day. In all, 46 of Allende's elite guard (the GAP, ''Grupo de Amigos Personales'') were killed, some of them in combat with the soldiers that took the Moneda.{{cite web|url=http://www.globalpolicy.org/component/content/article/165/29585.html|title=Pinochet Stripped of Legal Immunity|author=Administrator|publisher=globalpolicy.org}} Allende's Cuban-trained guard would have had about 300 elite commando-trained GAP fighters at the time of the coup,''The Nixon Administration and the Death of Allende's Chile: A Case of Assisted Suicide'', Jonathan Haslam, page 64, Verso Press 2005 but the use of brute military force, especially the use of [[Hawker Hunters]] fighter-bombers, may have handicapped many GAP fighters from further action. On the military side, there were 34 deaths: two army sergeants, three army corporals, four army privates, 2 navy lieutenants, 1 navy corporal, 4 naval cadets, 3 navy conscripts and 15 carabineros. Most of the ''carabineros'' were killed after two busloads of policemen were heavily engaged by armed leftists in the Pro-Allende shantytown of [[La Ligua]].''The Dictator's Shadow: Life Under Augusto Pinochet'', Heraldo Muñoz, p. 19, Basic Books, 2008 In Mid-September, the Chilean military junta claimed its troops suffered another 16 dead and 100 injured by gunfire in mop-up operations against Allende supporters, and Pinochet warned, ''"sadly there are still some armed groups who insist on attacking, which means that the military rules of wartime apply to them."''{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=nRMyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=96EFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2709,16507&dq|title=Chile Warns Armed Civilians|agency=AP|work=The Montreal Gazette}} 22-year-old Corporal Hugo Yáñez Durán would be among the army fallen, killed on 15 September 1973 in a shootout with leftists students holding out in the grounds of the University of Chile.La Verdad Olvidada del Terrorismo en Chile, 1968-1996, Arturo Castillo Vicencio, p. 87, Editorial Maye Ltda, 2007] On 23 October 1973, 23-year-old Army Corporal Benjamín Alfredo Jaramillo Ruz, who was serving with the ''Cazadores'', became the first fatal casualty of the counterinsurgency operations in the mountainous area of Alquihue in [[Valdivia]] after being shot by a sniper.''Informe de la Comisión Nacional de Verdad y Reconciliación'', Volume I, Page 441, Santiago, Chile, 1991. (SM, V, Chro) The Chilean Army suffered 12 killed in various clashes with MIR guerrillas and GAP fighters in October 1973.[https://web.archive.org/web/20080411012053/http://www.despiertachile.cl/2001/agosto/hojasagosto/edicion2.htm MÁRTIRES DE LAS FF.AA., DE ORDEN Y SEGURIDAD ] On 18 November 1974, guerrillas open fire on an army vehicle, killing Corporal Francisco Cifuentes Espinoza.Chile: Crónica de un asedio, 4 t., Luis Heinecke Scott, p 27, Sociedad Editora y Grafica Santa Catalina, 1992 On 17 November, MIR guerrillas shoot and kill army sergeant Waldo Morales Neal and private Clemente Santibáñez Vargas. On 7 November 1973, guerrillas open fire on an army truck in the suburb of La Florida in Santiago, killing private Agustín Correa Contreras. On 13 November, MIR guerrillas killed army corporal Juan Castro Vega. On 27 November, MIR guerrillas kill army corporal Ramón Madariaga Valdebenito. On 3 December 1973, MIR guerrillas kill two army corporals, Rodolfo Peña Tapia and Luis Collao Salas and a private, Julio Barahona Aranda. On 13 December 1973, guerrillas open fire and kill two army sergeants, Sergio Cañón Lermanda and Pedro Osorio Guerrero. On 15 December 1973, guerrillas shoot and kill army corporal Roberto Barra Martínez in the suburb of La Reina in Santiago. On 26 December 1973, guerrillas open fire on an army jeep, killing private José Luis Huerta Abarca. By the end of the year, the Chilean police would claim to have uncovered a huge arms cache, that included 5,000 HK-33 sub-machineguns and corresponding ammunition numbering in the millions and large quantities of 20-mm anti-tank gun shells.Victoria sin guerra, Graf Hans Huyn, p. 280, Andres Bello, 1987 ==1974–1979== On February 19, 1975, four captured MIR commanders went on national television to urge their guerrillas to lay down their arms. According to them, the MIR leadership was in ruins: of the 52 commanders of the MIR, nine had been killed, 24 were prisoners, ten were in exile, one had been expelled from the group, and eight were still at large.{{cite web|url=http://latinamericanhistory.about.com/od/thehistoryofchile/a/09ChileMIR_2.htm|title=Chile's MIR: The Revolutionary Left Movement|author=Christopher Minster |publisher=About.com}} On 18 November 1975, [[Revolutionary Left Movement (Chile)|MIR]] guerrillas killed a 19-year-old army conscript (Private Hernán Patricio Salinas Calderón).''Informe Rettig''. Volume II. Page 605. Chile) On 24 February 1976, MIR guerrillas in a gunbattle with Chilean secret police, shot and killed a 41-year-old carabinero sergeant (Tulio Pereira Pereira).''Informe de la Comisión Nacional de Verdad y Reconciliación'', Volume II, Page 605, Santiago, Chile, 1991. (SM, V, Chro) The Chilean secret police on this occasion were met with a hail of automatic weapons fire, killing a carabinero and a girl.{{cite web |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=CwI1AAAAIBAJ&sjid=VU8KAAAAIBAJ&pg=3351,2651922&dq=|title=Shootout kills 5 in Chile capital|agency=AP|work=Bangor Daily News}} On 28 April 1976, MIR guerrillas shot and killed a 29-year-old carabineros corporal (Bernardo Arturo Alcayaga Cerda) while he was walking home in the Santiago suburb of Pudahuel. On 16 October 1977, MIR guerrillas exploded 10 bombs in Santiago. In 1978 the MIR sought to reestablish a guerrilla front in southern Chile and launched Operation ''Return'' which involved clandestine entry, recruitment, bombings and bank robberies in Santiago that briefly shook the military regime.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ztjV7GVNeiAC&pg=PA81&dq=MIR+terrorists+chile&as_brr=3#v=onepage&q=&f=false|title=State Terrorism in Latin America|publisher=}} In February 1979 MIR guerrillas bombed the US-Chile Cultural Institute in Santiago, causing considerable damage. In 1979, about 40 bombings were blamed on MIR guerrillas. Several police, military and civilians caught in the crossfire and bomb blasts were killed in the renewed MIR attacks in the Chilean capital and at least 70 soldiers and policemen were wounded battling the marxist guerrillas."La última víctima fue un sargento de Carabineros. Y más o menos 70 quedaron heridos en combate" Los Comunistas y la Democracia, Luis Corvalán, p. 49, Lom Ediciones, 2008 ==Neltume Guerrilla Front== In order to reinforce urban guerrilla warfare waged in the main cities, the MIR commanders in 1978 had set in motion [[Operación Retorno]] (Operation ''Return''), ordering exiled militants back into Chile. In 1980, a platoon of thirty well-equipped MIR combatants of the ''Toqui Lautaro'' Battalion infiltrated into the mountains of Neltume in southern Chile and reestablished a guerrilla front. The MIR spearhead was commanded by 30-year-old Miguel Cabrera Fernández (nome de guerre ''Paine''), who along with 120-150 Chileans had completed their training for this operation in Czechoslovakia, Cuba and North Korea.''Neltume 81'' (Chilean TV documentary), 2012 The Chilean Army moved against the guerrillas in Neltume in June 1981, in a massive operation spearheaded by the Chilean Para-Commandos (elite Black Berets) all under the command of Colonel Orlando Basauri, with support from 10 Puma and Lama helicopters. Flora Jaramillo had fed and attended three MIR guerrillas that had sought refuge in her house, and not wanting to be later accused of collaborating with the enemy had sent her 15-year-old son Juan Carlos Henríquez Jaramillo to warn the local police station. Carabineros soon surrounded her house and opened fire, killing all the guerrillas and destroying the house, but not before warning Mrs Jaramillo to get out. The Special Forces involved discovered the first guerrilla arms cache on 25 June killing Raúl Rodrigo Obregón Torres (nome de guerre ''Pablo'') in the process, and four more store dumps were uncovered by the end of the first week in July. Another gun-battle took place on 28 June, but it took some time before Basauri's men could corner the guerrilla force.Chile Under Pinochet, Mark Ensalaco, p. 146, University of Pennsylvania Press, 2010 Nevertheless, seven MIR guerrillas were reported killed in an ambush in the third week of September, just after the 8th-anniversary of the 1973 military coup, but the survivors were able to escape and blend in with the local population. On 19 September 1981, Army Private Victor Manuel Nahuelpan Silva is killed during operations in Neltume. On 16 October 1981, Juan Angel Ojeda Aguayo (nom de guerre ''Pequeco'') who had escaped the mountain fighting was caught and executed while resting at his parent's home. Miguel Cabrera Fernández was himself killed on 15 October 1981, in a clash with policemen at Choshuenco. The Pinochet regime launched another counterinsurgency operation in August 1984 to wipe out the remaining guerrillas, concentrating in the areas around Concepción, Valdivia and Los Angeles, killing seven more MIR fighters and forcing the remainder to go into permanent hiding. Some forty MIR fighters lost their lives between 1978 (when Operation ''Return'' was set in motion) and 1984 when the MIR insurgency was finally defeated in southern Chile. Another 41 supporting [[Mapuche]] Indians that had earlier on taken part in the land and business takeovers under Salvador Allende were killed with 80 only spared after having been rounded up in and around Neltume and held for long periods in secret detention camps.''"En los informes sobre derechos humanos se establece que en este período hubo 41 ejecutados políticos y más de 80 detenidos desaparecidos de origen mapuche."'' Los Comunistas y la Democracia, Luis Corvalán, p. 74, Lom Ediciones, 2008 Guillermina Reinante, had three brothers rounded up and forcibly disappeared up by soldiers from the 8th ''Tucapel'' Infantry Regiment in late 1973. When she enquired about their whereabouts a female military official informed her that they had been executed. In the 2012 Chilean TV documentary ''Neltume 81'' Reinante claimed that the military had executed her brothers in revenge for taking part in the land expropriations. ==1980–1989== [[File:Protestas Chile 1985.jpg|thumb|left|Pacific protest against Pinochet]] On 15 July 1980, three guerrillas in blue overalls and yellow hardhats ambushed the car of Lieutenant-Colonel Roger Vergara Campos, director of the Chilean Army Intelligence School, and killed him and wounded his driver in a barrage of bullets from AK-47 assault rifles.{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=D-wVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QBMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6917,3235454&dq=carabineros+killed+chile |work=Star-News |title=Chile's Intelligence Chief Killed in Ambush|agency=AP}} On 30 December 1980, MIR guerrillas kill two carabineer corporals, 31-year-old Washington Godoy Palma and 27-year-old Daniel Alberto Leiva González.''Informe de la Comisión Nacional de verdad y Reconciliación'' Tomo 2 pp. 674–675 In a message sent to Santiago press agencies in February 1981 the [[Revolutionary Left Movement (Chile)|MIR]] claimed to have carried out more than 100 attacks during 1980, among them the bombing of electricity pylons in Santiago and Valparaiso on November 11 which caused widespread blackouts, and bomb attacks on three banks in Santiago on December 30 in which one carabinero was killed and three people wounded.{{cite web|title=Inauguration of President Pinochet for Further Term |author=Devo Forbes |url=http://www.britishcouncil.org/learnenglish-central-history-pinochet.htm |work= |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5j68T4t4h?url=http://www.britishcouncil.org/learnenglish-central-history-pinochet.htm |archivedate=2009-08-17 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2009-08-15 }} On 19 September 1981, Army Private Victor Manuel Nahuelpan Silva is killed during counter-insurgency operations in the Neltume area.Chile, Crónica de un asedio, 4 t., Luis Heinecke Scott, p 34, Sociedad Editora y Grafica Santa Catalina, 1992 In November 1981, MIR guerrillas killed three member of Police Investigations as they stood in front of the home of the chief minister of the presidential staff. In sweeps carried out from June to November 1981, security forces destroyed two MIR bases in the mountains of [[Neltume, Chile|Neltume]], seizing large caches of munitions and killing a number guerrillas.[http://www.faqs.org/cia/docs/33/0000451376/LATIN-AMERICA-REVIEW---CHILE:--TERRORISM-STILL-COUNTERPRODUCTIVE.html Chile: Terrorism still counterproductive. CIA document] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604160510/http://www.faqs.org/cia/docs/33/0000451376/LATIN-AMERICA-REVIEW---CHILE%3A--TERRORISM-STILL-COUNTERPRODUCTIVE.html |date=June 4, 2011 }} MIR guerrillas retaliated and carried out twenty-six bomb attacks during March and April 1983. Leftist guerrillas, waiting in a yellow pick-up truck, ambushed on 30 August 1983 the governor of Santiago, retired Major-General Carol Urzua Ibáñez as he left his home, killing him and two of his bodyguards (army corporals Carlos Riveros Bequiarelli and José Domingo Aguayo Franco) in a hail of submachine-gun fire.[Miami Herald, August 31, 1983] In October and November 1983, MIR guerrillas bombed four US-associated targets. Guerrillas killed two policemen (carabinieri Francisco Javier Pérez Brito and sergeant Manuel Jesús Valenzuela Loyola) on 28 December 1983.{{cite web|title=Despierta chile |url=http://www.despiertachile.cl/2006/dic06/html/martires.html |work= |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5j68UNfDn?url=http://www.despiertachile.cl/2006/dic06/html/martires.html |archivedate=2009-08-17 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2009-08-15 |df= }} On 31 March 1984, a police bus in downtown Santiago was destroyed with a bomb, killing a carabinero and injuring at least 11.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/31/world/around-the-world-bomb-kills-policeman-on-a-bus-in-santiago.html|title=AROUND THE WORLD - Bomb Kills Policeman On a Bus in Santiago |date=31 March 1984|work=New York Times}} On 29 April 1984, MIR guerrillas exploded 11 bombs, derailing a subway train in Santiago and injuring 22 passengers, including seven children.{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/30/world/around-the-world-bomb-derails-subway-in-chile-injuring-22.html|title=AROUND THE WORLD - Bomb Derails Subway In Chile, Injuring 22 |date=30 April 1984|work=New York Times}} On 5 September 1984, guerrillas shot and killed 27-year-old army lieutenant Julio Briones Rayo in Copiapó in northern Chile.''Informe de la Comisión Nacional de Verdad y Reconciliación'', Volume II, Page 680, Santiago, Chile, 1991. (SM, V, Chro) On 2 November 1984, a bus carrying carabineros was attacked with a grenade during Chile's national cycling championship; four carabineros were killed.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hzrwMb3UppYC&pg=PA140&lpg=PA140&dq=Luis+Fontaine,+carabineros&source=bl&ots=-67tt6vDua&sig=Y-p669NTCSN-04XaJc9_qK1z17I&hl=en&ei=a0eGSo2INZzW7AP9uPT6Aw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3#v=onepage&q=Luis%20Fontaine%2C%20carabineros&f=false|title=Chile Under Pinochet|publisher=}} On 4 November 1984, five guerrillas riding in a van hurled bombs and fired automatic weapons at a suburban Santiago police station, killing two carabineros and wounded three more.''Miami Herald'', November 5, 1984 On 7 December 1984, urban guerrillas killed a policeman and bombed a subway station, wounding 6 people.{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=QywhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=yn4EAAAAIBAJ&pg=7086,8371231&dq=|work=The Milwaukee Journal - Google News Archive Search|publisher=google.com}} On 25 March 1985, MIR guerrillas planted a bomb in Hotel Araucano in Concepcion that killed marine sergeant René Osvaldo Lara Arriagada and army sergeant Alejandro del Carmen Avendaño Sánchez, who were attempting to defuse the bomb. On 6 December 1985, a carabinero (Patricio Rodriguez Núñez) was shot to death by four guerrillas who opened fire on him with submachine-guns as he walked home.''Miami Herald'', December 8, 1985 That same month, 15 city buses were destroyed with gasoline bombs and urban guerrillas hurled a bomb under an incoming train in Santiago, before making good their escape after a shootout with policemen.{{cite web |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=5WAPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=soYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5350,1486376&dq=|work=The Bulletin |title=Terrorists Raid Train Station |date=December 10, 1985|agency=AUPI}} The total number of documented terrorist actions during 1984 and 1985 was 866.{{cite web|url=http://www.country-data.com/cgi-bin/query/r-2562.html|title=Chile - Terrorism|publisher=country-data.com}} On 5 February 1986, a car bomb destroyed a bus filled with riot police, mutilating 16 policemen. One carabinero (41-year-old Sergeant Luis Rival Valdés) later died of his wounds.[http://interactivos.museodelamemoria.cl/victimas/?p=1310 RIVAL VALDES LUIS HERNAN] The MIR claimed responsibility for the bombing.{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=F8wmAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5AEGAAAAIBAJ&pg=4746,1379382&dq=bomb%20+bus+santiago&hl=en|title=The Miami News - Google News Archive Search|work=google.ca}} On 17 February 1986, two trains crashed in an area of Limache that had been reduced to one track after MIR guerrillas had destroyed a nearby bridge,{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=V4kxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=66UFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2445,4396106&dq=|title=The Montreal Gazette - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com}} killing 100 and wounding 500 civilians.{{cite web|url=http://elpais.com/diario/1986/02/19/internacional/509151616_850215.html|title=100 muertos y 500 heridos en un choque de trenes en Chile|author=Ediciones El País|work=EL PAÍS}} On 26 February 1986, unidentified guerrillas or their sympathizers shoot and kill carabineer Lieutenant Alfonso Mauricio Rivera López."Informe de la Comisión Nacional de verdad y Reconciliación" Tomo 2 pp. 686 In May 1986 MIR guerrillas threw sulphuric acid into a bus, seriously injuring six people, including two children.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=55BZmIJ9xd8C&pg=PA98&dq=sulphuric+acid+terrorist+group+profiles#v=onepage&q=&f=false|title=Terrorist Group Profiles |publisher=}} On 25 July 1986, a bomb planted in a trash can exploded at a crowded bus stop a few yards from the presidential palace, wounding 36 people.La Verdad Olvidada del Terrorismo en Chile, 1968-1996, Arturo Castillo Vicencio, p. 131, Editorial Maye Ltda, 2007]{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=-hUpAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QYQDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4042,4149918&dq=bomb+%20bus+santiago&hl=en|title=The Deseret News - Google News Archive Search|work=google.ca}} On 6 August 1986, security forces discovered 80 tons of weapons at the tiny fishing harbor of [[Carrizal Bajo]], smuggled into the country by the [[Manuel Rodríguez Patriotic Front]] (FPMR). The shipment of Carrizal Bajo included C-4 [[plastic explosive]]s, 123 [[RPG-7]] and 180 [[M72 LAW]] rocket launchers as well as 3,383 [[M16 (rifle)|M-16]] rifles.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=itzzT3or3noC&pg=PA147&dq=Carrizal+Bajo+m+16+fpmr&as_brr=3&cd=2#v=onepage&q=Carrizal%20Bajo%20m%2016%20fpmr&f=false |title=Pinochet S.A.|publisher=RIL Editores |date=2006 |author=Ozren Agnic Krstulovic}} On 7 September 1986, about 30 [[FPMR]] guerrillas attempted to kill Pinochet. Pinochet narrowly escaped the assassination attempt on his motorcade, but five army corporals were killed and eleven soldiers and carabineros were wounded in the ambush.{{cite web|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,962342,00.html|title=Chile Pinochet's New State of Siege|date=22 September 1986|work=Time}} This failed operation led to an internal crisis of the group, many of its leading members being arrested by the security forces. On 28 October 1986, MIR guerrillas operating in Limache shot and wounded five policemen. One carabinero NCO (36-year-old Luis Serey Abarca) later died of his wounds.[http://interactivos.museodelamemoria.cl/victimas/?p=1606 SEREY ABARCA LUIS HUMBERTO] On 5 November 1986, guerrillas threw an incendiary bomb into a bus in Viña del Mar, seriously injuring three women (Rosa Rivera Fierro, Sonia Ramírez Salinas and Marta Sepúlveda Contreras). 37-year-old Rosa Rivera Fierro, later died of her wounds.[http://interactivos.museodelamemoria.cl/victimas/?p=1906 RIVERA FIERRO ROSA EUGENIA] On 28 November 1986, MIR guerrillas after having been stopped by a police vehicles, shot and killed 31-year-old carabinero Lieutenant Jaime Luis Sáenz Neira.[http://interactivos.museodelamemoria.cl/victimas/?p=2395 SAENZ NEIRA JAIME LUIS ] On 11 September 1987, a police vehicle was completely destroyed in a bomb attack in Santiago, killing two carabineros. On 20 January 1988, a bomb planted by MIR guerrillas in the Capredena Medical Center in Valparaiso killed a 64-year-old female pensioner (Berta Rosa Pardo Muñoz) and wounded 15 other women.''Informe de la Comisión Nacional de Verdad y Reconciliación'', Volume I, Page 692, Santiago, Chile, 1991. (SM, V, Chro) On January 26, MIR guerrillas planted a bomb in a house in La Cisterna that killed 42-year-old Major Julio Eladio Benimeli Ruz, commander of the carabineros special operations group. In June 1988, MIR guerrillas conducted a series of bombings in Santiago, at various banks. FPMR guerrillas that month killed 43-year-old Lieutenant-Colonel Miguel Eduardo Rojas Lobos of the Chilean Army, after he had parked his car in the Santiago suburb of San Joaquín.''Informe Rettig''. Volume II. Page 695. Chile) On 19 July 1988, leftists plant a bomb near a Church in Valparaíso, wounding three local churchgoers (Juan Salazar Olivares, Nelson Pérez and Luis Herrera)''El 19 de julio de 1988, explotó en Valparaíso, en la cercanía de una iglesia, una bomba de tiempo. Resultando gravemente heridos algunos feligreses que se disponían a entrar para participar en una ceremonia religiosa: Juan Salazar Olivares, Nelson Pérez y Luis Herrera.'' La Verdad Olvidada del Terrorismo en Chile, 1968-1996, Arturo Castillo Vicencio, Pagen 150, Editorial Maye Ltda., 2007 In October 1988, several platoons of the ''Frente Patriótico Manuel Rodríguez'' take over four important towns throughout the country, Aguas Grandes, La Mora, Los Queñes and Pichipellahuén.[http://kaosenlared.net/chile-una-historia-del-fpmr-la-ultima-orden-benjamin/ Una historia del FPMR: La última orden de Benjamín] Considerable fighting takes place, before the Chilean military and police are able to recover the towns.''A comienzos de noviembre se logra desarticular al grupo terrorista perteneciente al FMR que ha atacado en octubre el retén de la localidad fronteriza de Los Queñes, hecho enmarcado en la llamada Guerra Popular Prolongada.'' Chile Ecoge La Libertad, Gonzalo Rojas Sánchez, Page 784, Zig Zag, 1998 Corporal Juvenal Sepúlveda Vargas is killed defending the Police Station in Los Queñes.''El 21 de octubre de 1988, Cabo 2o de Carabineros Juvenal VARGAS SEPULVEDA, de 34 años, perteneciente a la dotación del Retén Los Queñes, provincia de Curicó, fue asesinado en un ataque a su unidad.'' La Verdad Olvidada del Terrorismo en Chile, 1968-1996, Arturo Castillo Vicencio, Pagen 150, Editorial Maye Ltda., 2007 On 10 July 1989, 26-year-old carabineros corporal Patricio Rubén Canihuante Astudillo was shot in the head at point-blank range as he guarded a building in Viña del Mar. In December 1989, Canadian police reported that 30 Brazilian business executives had been targeted for abduction by MIR guerrillas that included two Canadians, Christine Lamont and David Spencer who had joined the movement after meeting two exiled Chileans, Sergeo Olivares and Martin Urtubia, who came to Canada in 1978.{{cite web|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/thestar/doc/436081902.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Dec%2031,%201989&author=Dale%20Brazao%20Toronto%20Star&pub=Toronto%20Star&edition=&startpage=&desc=Brazil%20probes%20Canadians'%20terror%20links|title=Brazil probes Canadians' terror links|work=The Star}} ==Post-dictatorship violence== The election of a civilian government in Chile did not end guerrilla activities. Within a few months after President [[Patricio Aylwin]]'s accession to power, leftist militants showed that they remained committed to armed struggle and were responsible for a number of terrorist incidents. On May 10, 1990, two guerrillas wearing school uniforms killed ''carabineros'' Colonel Luis Fontaine, a former head of the antiterrorist unit of the carabiniers, Chile's national police force. Two policemen were killed on August 10, 1990, in a working-class Santiago suburb and two more were injured in an attack on a bus.''Chicago Tribune', August 12, 1990 In September 1990, leftist militants detonate 53 bombs that kill or wound 83 Chileans.''"Así llega a cuadruplicarse a fines del mismo año, cuando en el mes de septiembre detonaron 53 bombas, resultando de ello 83 víctimas entre muertos y heridos."'' Estudios Públicos, (Issues 41-42), p. 477, El Centro, 1991 On November 14, 1990, gendarmes transferred Marco Ariel Antonioletti, a senior MJL leader from jail to a hospital for treatment. MJL guerrillas fought their way into the Sótero del Río Hospital but were forced to withdraw, after having killed four gendarmes and one ''carabinero''. In retaliation, Chile's Investigations Police execute Antonioletti with a shot in the forehead. On January 24, 1991, MJL guerrillas ambushed and killed two carabineros. On February 28, 1991, a carabinero policeman died in a shoot-out in Santiago with leftist guerrillas of the Manuel Rodríguez Patriotic Front.''Miami Herald'', March 5, 1991 On April 1, FPMR guerrillas assassinated right-wing senator Jaime Guzman, killing him as he left a university campus in Santiago. On September 9 three guerrillas kidnapped Cristian Edwards, whose family run El Mercurio newspaper. After his family paid $1 million in ransom, the [[FPMR]] freed him. On 22 January 1992, two FPMR guerrillas (Fabián López Luque and Alex Muñoz Hoffman) were killed trying to rob a ''Prosegur'' cash delivery armoured van at the Pontifical Catholic University in Santiago. On September 11, 1998, three police stations—La Pincoya, La Granja and La Victoria—were attacked with firearms, incendiary bombs and rocks and 36 were carabineros were wounded in violence related to the 25th anniversary commemorations of the military coup.[https://archive.is/20121127131656/http://www.greenleft.org.au/1998/334/20295 Chile: coup anniversary brings heavy repression, 23 September 1998] In 2006, on the 33rd anniversary of the September 11, 1973, military coup, 79 carabineros were wounded in clashes with rioters.{{cite web |url=http://en.mercopress.com/2006/09/13/shooting-looting-and-arson-on-chile-september-11-anniversary|title=Shooting, looting and arson on Chile September 11 anniversary|work=MercoPress}} In September 2007, a carabinero policeman was killed after being shot in the face and around 40 were wounded during clashes with leftists marking the 34th anniversary of the military coup.http://www.news.com.au/couriermail/story/0,23739,22410450-23109,00.html The following month, MJL guerrillas killed carabineer Luis Moyano Farías during the robbery of Banco Security in Santiago. In clashes with protesters commemorating the 35th anniversary of the military coup, 29 carabineros were wounded in September 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.elcolombiano.com/BancoConocimiento/I/in_saldo_aniversario_chile_12092008/in_saldo_aniversario_chile_12092008.asp?CodSeccion=5|title=Unos 31 heridos y 234 detenidos en aniversario del golpe militar en Chile|work=El Colombiano}} In September 2009, 19 Carabineros were wounded in clashes with protestors marking the 36th anniversary of the coup.{{cite web|url=http://www.levante-emv.com/internacional/2009/09/13/internacional-tres-jovenes-muertos-chile-protestas-antipinochetistas/630544.html|title=Tres jvenes muertos en Chile en protestas antipinochetistas|author=Levante-EMV|publisher=levante-emv.com}} The lootings and other forms of appropriation that took place in the aftermath of the devastating 2010 earthquake in Chile, were in part promoted and legitimated by the MIR movement.{{cite web|url=http://www.workers.org/2010/world/chile_0311/|title=MIR in Chile: 'Expropriation is a people's right' |publisher=workers.org}} ==See also== * [[Dirty War]] * [[Day of the Young Combatant]] * [[Chile bombings from 2005]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Armed resistance in Chile (1973-90)}} [[Category:Communist rebellions]] [[Category:Guerrilla wars]] [[Category:Military dictatorship of Chile (1973–1990)]] [[Category:Rebellions in Chile]] [[Category:Resistance movements]]

{{coord|28.543|-81.379472|display=title}} {{Infobox building | name = Beacham Theatre | logo = File:The Beacham logo.png | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | image = The Beacham Theatre facade 9-9-2016.jpg | image_alt = | caption = Exterior of venue (c.2016) | former_names = Beacham Theatre {{small|(1921-1976; 2011-present)}}
Great Southern Music Hall {{small|(1976-81)}}
Laser World {{small|(1981-82)}}
Moulin Orange {{small|(1983-84)}}
Celebrity Dinner Theater {{small|(1984-87)}}
Pure Energy {{small|(1989-92)}}
Dekko's {{small|(1992-94)}}
Zuma Beach Club {{small|(1994-2000)}}
Tabu {{small|(2001-10)}} | alternate_names = | status = | building_type = [[Theater (building)|Theater]] | architectural_style = [[Commercial style|Commercial]], [[Art Deco]] and [[Mediterranean Revival]] | address = 46 N Orange Ave
[[Orlando, Florida|Orlando, FL]] 32801-2419 | location_city = | location_country = | current_tenants = | start_date = | completion_date = December 9, 1921 | seating_capacity = 1,250 | inauguration_date = | renovation_date = 1936, 1953, 1976, 1981, 1984, 1988, 1992, 2000 | demolition_date = | destruction_date = | height = | diameter = | floor_count = | floor_area = {{convert|30,965 |sqfoot}} | client = [[Braxton Beacham]] Sr. | owner = Beacham Theatre, LLC. (Missy Casscells and Frank Hamby) | other_dimensions = {{convert|145|ft}} across x {{convert|213.5|ft}} deep | architect = | architecture_firm = | main_contractor = | structural_system = Reinforced concrete and brick with stucco out-surface | coordinates = | map_type = | map_size = | embedded = | url = {{URL|http://www.thebeacham.com/|Venue Website}} }} The '''Beacham Theatre''' is a [[Cinema (building)|cinema]] built in 1921 by [[Braxton Beacham]] Sr. in the city of [[Orlando, Florida|Orlando]], [[Florida]]. The current address of the theater is 46 North Orange Avenue, and it is located at the southwest corner of Orange Avenue and Washington Street. The building's current lack of impressive [[architecture]] is offset by its significant [[cultural history]].{{cite web |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1988-02-28/news/0020190106_1_tampa-theatre-beacham-theater-in-atlanta |title=Conflict Now Playing At Beacham Owner: Destroy It -- Activists: Save It |last1= Dezern |first1=Craig |date=February 28, 1988 |website=orlandosentinel.com |publisher=''The Orlando Sentinel'' |access-date=August 11, 2016 |quote=But when preservationists look, they see a landmark. Square columns adorned with feathered capitals climb gracefully to a high ceiling decorated with rectangles of intricate plasterwork. An orchestra pit and the gentle slope of the auditorium floor wait, covered by modern alterations. The debate between progress and preservation has played in old theaters throughout the South, and sometimes preservation has won. But for every theater saved, two more meet the wrecking ball. The Beacham soon may join the fallen theaters. Juarez, a developer and political consultant, has applied for permission to tear down the building at 46 N. Orange Ave., and the Beacham lacks key elements that saved movie palaces in Tampa, Atlanta and Lakeland. Impressive architecture is one of those elements.}}{{cite web |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1988-02-10/news/0010430175_1_historic-building-city-council-juarez |title=Beacham: The End Or A Full New Show? |last1= Blumenstyk |first1=Goldie|date=February 10, 1988|website=orlandosentinel.com |publisher=''The Orlando Sentinel'' |access-date=August 11, 2016|quote=}}{{Cite journal|last=Wilkening|first=David|date=February 1988|title=Can they save the Beacham?|url=|journal=Orlando Magazine|publisher=Orlando Magazine|volume=|issue=|doi=|pmid=|access-date=|via=City of Orlando Historic Preservation, Beacham File}} The Beacham Theatre was considered an important contributing structure when the [[Downtown Orlando]] [[historic district]] was created in 1980 and the building was granted local [[landmark]] status in 1987."The Beacham Theatre," City of Orlando, Historic Preservation Board The Beacham was once part of the [[vaudeville]] circuit and hosted celebrity acts such as [[John Phillip Sousa]], the [[Ziegfeld Follies]] and [[W.C. Fields]], whose signature was once visible inside a dressing room. In the eras of [[silent film]] and [[Classical Hollywood cinema#Classical Hollywood cinema In the Sound Era (late 1920s – 1960)|Classical Hollywood cinema]], the Beacham was operated as a [[movie theater]] that utilized then-current [[state-of-the-art]] [[Film|motion picture]] technology. '''The Beacham''', as it is currently named, has since been used as a series of [[concert venue]]s and [[nightclub]]s thus saving it from [[demolition]]. The Beacham Theatre was once home to the late-night [[Underground culture|underground]] [[discotheque]] '''Aahz''' that is recognized internationally as a birthplace and critical component of the [[electronic dance music]] [[Clubbing (subculture)|movement]]. ==History== ===Construction=== [[file:Orange_County_Florida_Jail_(gaol)_photo.jpg|thumb|165px|left|The former Orange County Jail on the site of the Beacham Theatre]] The Beacham Theatre was constructed in 1921 by [[Braxton Beacham]] Sr., who had previously owned three other Orlando theaters{{cite magazine |author= |title=With "News" Correspondents (Florida) |url=https://archive.org/stream/motionpicturenew23moti_7#page/3198/mode/2up |magazine=Motion Picture News|location=New York|publisher=Motion Picture News, Inc. |date=May–June 1921 |access-date=February 17, 2017 }} and had served as [[Mayor of Orlando]] during 1907. In 1917 Beacham paid approximately $17,500–$20,000 for the property one block southwest of his stately residence on Jefferson Street after Orlando's citizens voted to pave the road to the [[cemetery]] instead of purchasing the old jail. The property he purchased had formerly served as the [[gaol|jail]] for [[Orange County, Florida|Orange County]] since about 1873.{{cite book|author1=Stephanie Gaub Antequino|author2=Tana Mosier Porter|author3=Historical Society of Central Florida|title=Lost Orlando|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4xWDRXbzXsMC|year=2012|publisher=Arcadia Publishing|isbn=978-0-7385-9173-5}} With a $200,000 investment, the former jail building was torn down in 1919 and Beacham developed a series of connected building units along the west side of Orange Avenue between Washington Street and Oak Street (now Wall Street). The new building was then known as "Beacham's Block" and is now known the Beacham Building. The location of Beacham's theater was precisely where several [[Capital punishment|condemned]] prisoners were executed by [[hanging]].{{cite magazine|last=Schaal Hinson|first=Sandra|date=February 1983|title=A mover behind shakers|url=|magazine=Orlando Magazine|location=Orlando|publisher=Orlando Magazine|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}{{Cite news|url=|title=Beacham Has Come Long Way: Lillian Gish to Queen Esther|last=Ives|first=Sidney|date=December 23, 1953|work=The Orlando Evening Star|access-date=|via=}}{{cite news |url= |title= Curtain rises on new act for Beacham|last1=Sweers |first1=Katheryn |date=July 12, 1981 |website= |publisher=The Orlando Sentinel |access-date= |quote=}}{{cite web |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1996-01-28/news/9601250598_1_orlando-opera-opera-house-movie-houses |title= Early Entertainment Venues Evolved From Opera House To Movie Theaters|last1=Andrews|first1=Mark|date=January 28, 1996 |website=orlandosentinel.com |publisher=The Orlando Sentinel |access-date= August 21, 2016|quote=...the former site of the county jail where hangings once were conducted - and built the Beacham Theater...Air conditioning was installed in the '30s...It later was home to Laser World; then to Moulin Orange, a Las Vegas-style cabaret that lasted four months in 1983-84; and then to Valentyne's Celebrity Dinner Theatre, which opened in 1987.}}{{Cite news|url=|title=Requiem for the Beacham Theatre|last=Means|first=Howard|date=October 17, 1982|work=The Orlando Sentinel|access-date=|via=}} According to local [[folklore]], the Beacham Building is reportedly [[ghost|haunted]].{{cite web |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2001-02-16/entertainment/0102150519_1_gavin-tour-downtown-orlando |title=A Jaunt Into Haunts |last1= Wallace Dickinson |first1= Joy |date=February 16, 2001 |website=orlandosentinel.com |publisher= ''The Orlando Sentinel'' |access-date= August 14, 2016|quote=Gavin's tour includes tales of a sensational murder across the street from the Angebilt in the vanished San Juan Hotel and of a secret tunnel connecting the Angebilt to the old Beacham Theater (now the Tabu night spot at 46 N. Orange). Which brings us to the ghost stories. Ghosts, it seems, are especially attracted to theaters, and Gavin's tour includes mentions of apparitions both at the Beacham and in several other theatrical venues}}{{cite web |url=http://www.hauntedplaces.org/item/tabu-nightclub-the-beacham/ |title=Tabu Nightclub - The Beacham |author= |date= |website=hauntedplaces.org |publisher=Haunted Places (blog) |access-date=August 14, 2016 |quote=}}{{cite web|url=http://pegasus.cc.ucf.edu/~joupage/evan/morgenstern.html|title=Orlando: the City Haunted|last=Anderson|first=Vanessa|date=2001|website=Orlando: the City Haunted|publisher=Knightwire|access-date=August 14, 2016|quote=|last1=|first1=}} The Beacham's [[auditorium]] features "square [[columns]] adorned with feathered [[Capital (architecture)|capitals]] that climb gracefully to a high ceiling decorated with rectangles of intricate [[plasterwork]]." When constructed, the theater was outfitted with [[Curtain|draperies]] that covered the plaster walls. The draperies had "mild tan figures delicately woven into the broad white field with an occasional soft blue figure" that were selected by Mrs. Roberta Holland Beacham, wife of Braxton Beacham Sr. [[File:Beacham Theater in 1921.jpg|thumb|230px|left|The Beacham Theatre shortly after construction in 1921]] Beacham outfitted his theater with innovative state-of-the art equipment from the Southern Theater Equipment Company of Atlanta.{{cite web |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1988-12-04/news/0090000006_1_bookhardt-beacham-sidewalks|title=1907: Beacham Elected Mayor|last1=Glover|first1=C.A.|date=December 4, 1988|website=orlandosentinel.com |publisher=''The Orlando Sentinel'' |access-date=August 16, 2016 |quote=}} The Beacham's box office in the lobby featured both an automatic [[admission ticket]] [[vending machine]] dispenser and ticket [[cutting|chopping]] machine. A decorative [[Marquee (sign)|marquee]] that was unique in Florida extended toward the street and featured an electric changeable sign that flashed the daily program. Two Powers 6B type "E" projectors were supplied by the N Power company of New York. The Midas Gold [[Projection screen|film screen]] was made especially for the Beacham. A medium-sized [[pipe organ]] from the [[Austin Organ Company]] of [[Hartford, Connecticut]], was purchased and installed at a cost of $15,000. The organ, [[List of pipe organs|Opus 1034]] with 3 [[Manual (music)|manual]]s in a center [[Organ console|console]], 24 ranks of [[Organ pipes|pipes]] and 24 [[Organ stop|stops]][http://www.austinorgans.com/aoisearchableopus.html Austin Organs Database], retrieved October 14, 2016. was played by both Mr. Herman Stuart and Mrs. Roberta Branch Beacham, wife of Braxton Beacham Jr. to accompany [[silent film]]s and [[vaudeville]] acts. Typhoon cooling and ventilating equipment was installed in the theater. The Beacham Building's construction featured numerous [[fireproofing]] and [[fire safety]] measures. When the theater opened, the auditorium had an operating capacity of 1400.{{cite news |author= |title=New Beacham is one of Refinement and Elegance: Equipment of New Beacham Theater is the Finest that is Obtainable. |url= |newspaper= The Evening Reporter-Star.|location=Orlando. |date=December 8, 1921 |access-date= }} [[Tunnels]] from the theater stage trap ran into the basements of two nearby hotels. The tunnels had low ceilings and were sealed during new construction in the early 1980s. The tunnels extended south into the [[San Juan Hotel]], where Mr. Beacham happened to have had an office, and then east under Orange Avenue into the [[Angebilt Hotel]]. Historians reason that the purpose of the tunnels may have been either for vaudeville performers to enter the theater from their hotels without being mobbed by crowds, or the tunnels could have been used for the storage and transportation of alcoholic beverages during prohibition as has been discovered at some of the other theaters in the Central Florida area.{{cite book|author=Steve Rajtar|title=A Guide to Historic Orlando|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3cZfqYU1B4cC&pg=PA58|year=2006|publisher=The History Press|isbn=978-1-59629-198-0|pages=58–}}{{cite web |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2007-02-10/news/HISTORYTRAILS_1_historic-trails-boy-scout-florida|title=Take a walk into Florida's past |last1=Shrieves |first1=Linda |date=February 10, 2007|website=orlandosentinel.com |publisher= ''The Orlando Sentinel''|access-date= August 5, 2016|quote=Behind the theater's backstage is a trap door to a tunnel that runs underneath Orange Avenue to the 11-story brick building that was once the grand Angebilt Hotel. The tunnel was built, he says, so that vaudeville stars appearing at the Beacham in the 1920s, '30s and '40s could slip back to the hotel after the show without being mobbed by fans.}}{{cite web |url=http://www.orlandomagazine.com/Orlando-Magazine/July-2012/Answer-Man/ |title= Digging into Orlando's Past: Is there a secret tunnel connecting the Beacham Theater and the old Angebilt Hotel? |author= |date=July 12, 2012 |website=orlandomagazine.com |publisher= Orlando Magazine|access-date=August 5, 2016 |quote=Another Orlando historian, Joy Wallace Dickinson, raises an intriguing possibility about the Beacham. Recently she toured some historic buildings in Tampa and learned that during renovation, crews came across subterranean spaces about 3 feet high that were used to hide booze during Prohibition.}} ===Vaudeville and Silent film era=== On December 9, 1921, Orlando's premier vaudeville and movie house opened by showing [[Norma Talmadge filmography|''The Wonderful Thing'']], starring [[Norma Talmadge]], a [[Pathé News]] [[newsreel]], and [[Buster Keaton]]'s ''[[The Boat (film)|The Boat]]''.Act Two: A Beacham History. 1985. Celebrity Dinner Theater.{{cite web |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2000-12-31/news/0012300184_1_magruder-carter-third-millennium |title=Hoofbeats Were Background To New Year's 1901 |author= |date=December 31, 2000 |website=orlandosentinel.com |publisher=''The Orlando Sentinel'' |access-date=August 4, 2016 |quote=}} The Beacham Theatre was originally the only [[sole proprietorship|independent]] theater in Orlando. However, the next year, in 1922, Beacham leased his theater to Mack Sparks of the Sparks Theater Company chain. [[File:San Juan Hotel and Beacham Theater - Orlando, Florida.jpg|thumb|230px|right|Beacham Theatre and San Juan Hotel circa 1923. Marquee: The Second Orlando Picture The Burned Crucifix]] The senior Braxton Beacham died in 1924 after a long illness, and Roberta Holland Beacham died soon after in 1926. Their [[Estate (law)|estate]] and [[real property]] were left to their [[child]]ren, Norma K. Hughes, Roberta Augusta Rogers, Braxton Beacham Jr., and his wife Roberta Branch Beacham. [[Florida]] and [[Orlando]] were on what was referred to by [[List of vaudeville performers: A–K|vaudeville performers]] as "[[Straw hat|The Straw Hat]] [[Atlantic Coast Line Railroad|Circuit]]." The Beacham Theatre was included on the [[Alexander Pantages]], [[Orpheum Circuit#Late circuit (1919–1928)|Orpheum]], and [[Keith-Albee Theatre|Keith-Albee]] vaudeville performance circuits (later combined as the [[Keith-Albee-Orpheum]] circuit). Manager Harry Vincent started several promotions at the Beacham Theatre in the summer months of the mid-1920s that included [[Raffle|Bank Night]], [[Talent show|Amateur Night]], and [[General store|Country Store Night]], which was supported by dozens of local [[merchant]]s. An [[magazine|advertisement]] for the Beacham in 1925 says, "Don't talk about the hot weather. Beat the heat in a Beacham seat. 'Kum Keep Kumfy Kool at the Beacham' is known to many and you won't enjoy yourself until you too get into the line that leads to comfort."What's What, Here and There as Recorded by "Bobby" (1925) magazine. Theatrical section via LMS, Orange County Public Library. Orlando. Frank Bell served as manager of the theater with [[organist]] Herman Siewart and Ken Guernsey leading the community [[sing-along]] at [[Forum (legal)|open forum]] meetings that were held for several months during the winter on Sunday afternoons. The Beacham's "[[Film promotion|exploitation]] director" Frank H. Burns often designed and created large elaborate [[standee|standing displays]] that decorated the facade and lobby of the theater in order to [[Out-of-home advertising|advertise]] new film features.{{Cite web|url=https://archive.org/stream/motionpicturenew00moti_7/motionpicturenew00moti_7_djvu.txt|title=Motion Picture News (May-Jun 1925)"|last=|first=|date=May 2, 1925|website=mediahistoryproject.org|publisher=The Museum of Modern Art Library coordinated by the Media History Digital Library|archive-url=https://archive.org/details/motionpicturenew00moti_7|archive-date=July 3, 2015|access-date=August 24, 2016}} The iconic displays that Burns created for the Beacham Theatre were sometimes complete with [[Costume coordination|coordinated costumes]] for the employees. In 1928 [[Vitaphone]] and [[Movietone sound system|Movietone]] [[Sound film|"talkie"]] equipment debuted during the city's first "Progress Week" during the last week of August. "The queen of the [[Femme fatale|vamps]]," [[actress]] [[Theda Bara]], was in appearance at the Beacham as [[secondary education in the United States|students]] from [[Orange County Public Schools#High schools|Orlando High School]] sneaked into the balcony via the [[fire escape]]. Sound was provided by two [[gramophone records|gramophone discs]] that accompanied each film. Both [[phonograph]]s were played simultaneously in case the needle skipped during a film. Output could be easily switched so that the film's sound could remain in [[synchronicity]] with the picture. William Booth succeeded Frank Bell as manager of the Beacham after Bell was transferred in 1928. The city's "[[Blue law|Sunday closing law]]" was repealed by [[Voting|voters]] in 1929 by a majority of only 59 votes. Movie theaters and other businesses in Orlando were then permitted to operate seven days a week. All of Orlando's theaters, including the Beacham, celebrated by showing free films until late into the night.{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=November 1996|title=Retroactively Speaking|url=|journal=Downtown Orlando Monthly|volume=|issue=|doi=|pmid=|access-date=|via=Theatre Historical Society of America}} ==== End of the vaudeville and silent film era ==== Interest in silent films began to diminish in 1929 and they were gradually phased out and moved into [[obsolescence]]. On Thursday evenings at the Beacham for the Bank Night promotion, $200 was [[raffle]]d with prizes of $50. On Saturday, December 24, 1931, and on Wednesday, September 28, 1932, a brand new $325 [[Austin 7#Austin Seven Swallow|Austin 7 Sport Roadster]] was given away. Vaudeville acts continued touring at the Beacham for several more years until approximately 1933. Homer Fuller served as manager of the Beacham during the end of the eras of silent films and vaudeville. In 1933 following a bitter [[lawsuit]] against Orlando Enterprises over nonpayment of the lease for the building that had been originally negotiated with the senior Braxton Beacham in 1924, the theater was closed for almost three weeks. $8000 in back taxes on Beacham's building was due. Beacham Jr. claimed the closure was deliberate and malicious and sued for $100,000. Two separate judgments were entered against Orlando Enterprises Inc. for $2291.67 each and a payment agreement was reached. Litigation was then withdrawn. As a result of the suit the lease was not renewed and Beacham's theater again became Orlando's only independent cinema.[https://orlandoretro.com/2013/04/18/beacham-movie-line-up-in-september-1933/ Beacham Movie Line Up in September 1933] (April 18, 2013), retrieved February 9, 2017 In the same year, the theater was soon leased Florida State Theaters. Harry Vincent was named manager of the reopened theater in 1933; however, soon after, Vernon D. Hunter became the theater's manager and remained in that role for the next two decades. ===First-Run Movie era=== In August 1937 the [[Orlando Police Department]] raided the Beacham Theatre. All of the equipment for the Bank Night [[Promotion (marketing)|marketing promotion]] was [[Search and seizure|seized]] after authorities declared it to be a [[lottery]].{{cite book|author=Eve Bacon|title=Orlando: A Centennial History|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4svzPQAACAAJ|year=1977|publisher=Mickler House}} ''[[The Yearling (film)|The Yearling]]'' was filmed locally in 1946 and the Beacham's [[projectionist]] Byram McGee served as an [[Electrician (theatre)|electrician]] and steward on the [[Production (film)|film production]]. Mcgee's wife Lois [[Actor|acted]] in the role of Ma Forrester and was also the production's [[wardrobe supervisor]]. Numerous other local [[technician]]s were involved with making the film. ''[[The Orlando Story]]'', filmed by Don Parrisher Motion Picture Productions of New York, contained images of daily life in Orlando. The movie was heavily promoted locally and was shown at the Beacham over three days in August 1949.{{cite web |url=http://dc.ocls.info/memory/document/orlando-story |title=The Orlando Story |author= |date=July 7, 2012 |website=Orlando Memory |publisher=Orange County Library System|access-date=August 5, 2016 |quote=...promoting a movie created about daily life in Orlando called ''The Orlando Story''. ... The film was shown for three days - August 11, 12, and 13 at ... the Beacham...These scenes were shot by Don Parrisher Motion Picture Productions, of New York, some months ago; now you can see them on the Beacham and Roxy screens.}} [[File:The Robe Beacham Theatre student ticket.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Student ticket for ''The Robe'' and the debut of CinemaScope at the Beacham Theatre]] In December 1949 ''The [[Tom Thumb]] [[Follies]]'' staged [[Radio in the United States#Local radio in the Golden Age|radio broadcast]] performances at the Beacham. When a [[Santa Claus]] from the [[Elks Lodge]] lifted one young elf into the audience for the last verse, the smell of [[bourbon whiskey]] caused her to ponder, "I wasn't just sure where the night's polka would land us. Maybe [[Wizard of Oz (1939 film)|Oz]]?"{{cite magazine |last=Weber III |first=Theodore H. |date=December 25, 1994 |title=Oh Little Town... |url= |magazine=Florida Magazine |location=Orlando |publisher=Florida magazine via Rollins College, Olin Library |access-date=}} After an extensive remodel, [[CinemaScope]] equipment was introduced at the "New" Beacham Theatre in 1954 with the addition of [[stereophonic sound]], new projection [[Lens (optics)|lens]]es, and a wider screen.{{cite web |url=http://www2.boxoffice.com/the_vault/issue_page?issue_id=1954-1-9&page_no=118#page_start|title=Impressive new Facade for Florida Theatre |author= |date=January 9, 1954|website=boxoffice.com |publisher=[[Boxoffice Magazine]] |access-date=August 11, 2016 |quote=}} CinemaScope had its debut at the Beacham on January 7, 1954, for a two-week showing of the film ''[[The Robe (film)|The Robe]]''.{{cite web |url= http://www.film-tech.com/ubb/f1/t011551.html|title=Looking back at CinemaScope: The Original Engagements of ''The Robe'' |last1= Coate |first1=Michael|date=September 16, 2013 |website=film-tech.com |publisher= |access-date=August 28, 2016 |quote=}} Vernon D. Hunter retired after 20 years as manager of the Beacham Theater. Walther Colby became the executive director of several Orlando theaters including the Beacham. Braxton Beacham Jr., died in 1961. [[File:Beacham Theatre Box Office.jpg|thumb|left|210px|The box office of the Beacham Theatre in March 1991. The 1954 box office was removed in 2000.]] During the [[Civil Rights Movement]], the Beacham Theatre had frequent [[Sit-in|stand-in protest]]s by [[African Americans|African American]] [[Citizenship|citizens]] of relegation to lesser "[[African-American|colored]] theaters" mandated by [[Jim Crow laws]] such as the [[Florida Constitution of 1885]]. [[Reverend]] [[Nelson Pinder]], of [[Parramore]]'s Episcopal Church of St. John the Baptist, along with other community leaders such as NAACP Youth Council advisor, Rev. Curtis Jackson, worked with white officials for peaceful integration in Orlando in order to avoid incidents of [[racial violence]] that were occurring in other Florida cities.{{cite web |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2010-01-08/news/os-father-pinder-recognitiion-20100108_1_episcopal-diocese-bishop-john-w-howe-episcopal-church-official |title=Episcopal diocese honors Nelson Pinder for 50 years in ministry|last1= Kunerth |first1=Jeff |date= January 8, 2010|website= |publisher=The Orlando Sentinel |access-date=August 30, 2016 |quote=}} Rev. Pinder organized the church's Liberal Religious Youth group.{{Cite web|url=https://ucf.digital.flvc.org/islandora/object/ucf%3A25551/datastream/OBJ/view/The_Florida_historical_quarterly.pdf |title=Segregation and Desegregation in Parramore: Orlando's African American Community|last=Mosier Porter|first=Tana|date=Winter 2004|website=The Florida Historical Quarterly. Volume 82, Number 3|publisher=The Florida Historical Society|access-date=August 23, 2016}}{{cite web |url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/features/os-black-teens-civil-rights-story.html |title=Teens spark Orlando's civil-rights era |last= Kunerth |first= Jeff|date=February 22, 2009 |website=orlandosentinel.com |publisher=''The Orlando Sentinel'' |access-date=November 21, 2016 |quote=Some of the youths worked with the Rev. Nelson Pinder, a young Episcopalian minister of the streets. Others, such as those arrested in March 1962, were members of the NAACP Youth Council, a local chapter started in 1959...Two months after being released from jail, Poston was arrested again for trying to integrate the Beacham Theater in downtown Orlando. Joining a group of black kids, Poston stood in line for tickets, was refused, got back in line and continued the routine until the last ticket was sold. Their courteous protest drew the attention of young white segregationists who threatened the black teens. Orlando police arrived and arrested the eight black students for "disturbing the peace." Police later said the blacks were taken into protective custody to prevent violence against them. All were released because they were underage -- except 18-year-old Sandra Poston, who called her mother from jail. "I thought, 'Here it goes again,' " her mother said. That charge and all the charges against the kids arrested at Stroud's were eventually dismissed...1963: Beacham Theater agrees to allow limited numbers of blacks at designated showings.}} Rev. Pinder's youth group protests were often joined by local members of the Youth Council of the [[National Association for the Advancement of Colored People]]. Each night, activist members of the youth groups quietly stood-in near the Beacham's ticket booth until the theater stopped selling tickets. On May 24, 1962, [[white supremacists]] were also [[picketing]] the Beacham at the same time as the Liberal Religious Youth group. Orlando police [[arrest]]ed eight teen protestors. The teens were kept in so-called [[Protective custody#Other usages|protective custody]] and were later released to their parents. Following agreements with a [[biracial]] [[committee]] from [[List of mayors of Orlando, Florida|Orlando Mayor]] [[Bob Carr (Florida politician)|Bob Carr]]'s office, of which Rev. Pinder was a member, the Beacham Theatre quietly began allowing a limited number of African-American patrons into the balcony for designated showings in 1963. The theater remained [[Racial segregation in the United States|racially segregated]] for African-American patrons until 1965.{{cite web |url=http://cinematreasures.org/theaters/10862 |title=Beacham Theater|last1=Jennings|first1=Samuel|date=June 18, 2011 |website= cinematreasures.org|publisher= Cinema Treasures|access-date=August 5, 2016|quote=}} In 1964 the theater was temporarily closed down while [[Cinerama]] equipment was installed. A super-wide [[Anamorphic widescreen|anamorphic movie screen]] was added to the auditorium and the stereophonic sound system was upgraded. Two [[Philips DP70|Norelco Universal 70/35mm Motion Picture Projector]]s and a small restroom for the projectionist were installed in a newly built downstairs projection booth under the balcony that required the removal of two aisles and several seats. Following the Beacham's upgrade to [[70 mm film]] technology, ''[[The Sound of Music (film)|The Sound of Music]]'' had a continuous 14-month run between 1965 and 1966. Orlando's [[Chamber of Commerce]] held open forum meetings at the Beacham Theatre on Sundays during the winter months of 1971-1973 under the direction of W. F. Blackman. ====End of the first-run movie era==== [[File:Old Beacham Theatre logo sticker.jpg|thumb|200px|left|1990's logo depicting the Beacham Theatre's mid-century marquee.]] During the 1970s Orlando, like many U.S. cites, was experiencing symptoms of [[urban decay]]. The rush from the city to the suburbs affected nearly all of the city's businesses. As an effect of the exodus, each of Downtown Orlando's movie theaters closed. Dick Gabel and John Prine were serving as projectionists at several of the theaters. Following a decline in attendance, by 1974 the Beacham Theatre and Florida State Theaters in general were primarily showing [[exploitation films]] and [[B movie#1970s|B-movie]] [[action films]]. The next year, H. A. Tedder, who was the Orlando executive manager at long-time [[lessee]] Florida State Theaters, made the decision that The Beacham Theatre would cease operating as a first-run movie cinema. After showing a Sunday double-feature of ''[[Return of the Street Fighter]]'', and [[The Scavengers (1969 film)|''The Scavengers'']], the Beacham Theatre's manager, McKinley Howard, closed the theater's doors as a first-run film cinema for the last time on September 28, 1975.Last picture Show: Beacham. September 28, 1975. Florida State Theaters remained responsible for paying the monthly lease of $2700 until the theater was sold. ===Live Entertainment era=== In 1975 Larry and Sherry Carpenter purchased the Beacham Building from then-owners, Betty Rubles Bray, and Burkett H. Bray Jr. A [[great-granddaughter]] of Braxton Beacham, Mrs. Bray, refused to sell the theater by itself without also selling the rest of the building as a package. An extensive $250,000 remodeling and restoration followed that included stunning multi-colored Art Deco revival style graphics painted over the facade and a large multi-story [[mural]] of a saxophone and its open case painted on the rear of the theater that faced west and was clearly visible from nearby [[Interstate 4]]. Following the restoration the Carpenters opened Orlando's [[Franchising|franchise]] location of '''The Great Southern Music Hall''' at the Beacham in 1976. The 700-seat Great Southern Music Hall was a [[concert venue]] that hosted approximately 180 prominent national and regional acts at the Beacham. The Great Southern Music Hall was occasionally still used as a movie theater that presented [[world cinema]] and [[Classical Hollywood cinema|classic Hollywood]] films by [[film director]]s such as [[John Carpenter]], [[Federico Fellini]], and [[Mel Brooks]] during the week. John Lawson was the acting projectionist and served as stage director for concerts. As The Great Southern Music Hall, only about seven music shows were unprofitable. Nevertheless, Orlando's Great Southern Music Hall closed in 1981 due to the rising costs of hosting concerts for [[Notability|notable]] musical acts and competition from larger venues.
